perturbation.original_text: Company shall sell and deliver as provided in Section 2.3 of this Agreement to Distributor on the price terms set forth in this Agreement or as amended from time to time such quantity of Products as Distributor from time to time orders from Company. Company shall promote and advertise the Products generally, at its own expense, and shall furnish Distributor copies at all advertisement and promotional materials.
perturbation.changed_text: Company shall endeavor to sell and deliver as provided in Section 2.3 of this Agreement to Distributor on the price terms set forth in this Agreement or as amended from time to time such quantity of Products as Distributor from time to time orders from Company. Company will attempt to promote and advertise the Products generally, at its own expense, and shall furnish Distributor copies of advertisement and promotional materials, if conveniently available.
perturbation.explanation: The original text contains a clear obligation on the Company to sell and deliver products as ordered. The modified text replaces 'shall sell and deliver' with 'shall endeavor to sell and deliver' and 'shall promote and advertise' with 'will attempt to promote and advertise'. It also makes the provision of promotional material depend on availability. This introduces ambiguity and makes the company's obligation discretionary, rather than mandatory.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Illinois Uniform Commercial Code - Obligation of Good Faith
perturbation.law_explanation: The modification weakens the commitment of the company to sell and deliver the products to the distributor, using terms like 'endeavor to' and 'attempt to', which introduces discretion. This could violate the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing under the Illinois Uniform Commercial Code (810 ILCS 5/1-304), which requires parties to a contract to act honestly and reasonably in its performance and enforcement. This modification allows the company to potentially avoid fulfilling orders or promoting the product, undermining the distributor's ability to succeed.
perturbation.scraped_snippet_1: 815 ILCS 617/ Euro Conversion Act. BUSINESS TRANSACTIONS (815 ILCS 617/) Euro Conversion Act. 815 ILCS 617/5 (815 ILCS 617/5) Sec. 5. Definitions. As used in this Act: "Euro" means the currency of participating member states of the European Union that adopt a single currency in accordance with the Treaty on European Union of February 7, 1992. "Introduction of the euro" includes the implementation from time to time of Economic and Monetary Union in member states of the European Union pursuant to the Treaty on European Union of February 7, 1992. "ECU" or "European Currency Unit" means the currency basket that is from time to time used as the unit of account of the European Community as defined in European Council Regulation No. 3320/94. (Source: P.A. 90-268, eff. 7-30-97.) 815 ILCS 617/10 (815 ILCS 617/10) Sec. 10. Continuity of contract. (a) If a subject or medium of payment of a contract, security, or instrument is a currency that has been substituted or replaced by the euro, the euro shall be a commercially reasonable substitute and substantial equivalent that may be either (i) used in determining the value of that currency or (ii) tendered, in each case at the conversion rate specified in, and otherwise calculated in accordance with, the regulations adopted by the Council of the European Union. (b) If a subject or medium of payment of a contract, security, or instrument is the ECU, the euro shall be a commercially reasonable substitute and substantial equivalent that may be either (i) used in determining the value of the ECU or (ii) tendered, in each case at the conversion rate specified in, and otherwise calculated in accordance with, the regulations adopted by the Council of the European Union. (c) Performance of any of the obligations described in subsections (a) or (b) of this Section may be made in the currency or currencies originally designated in the contract, security, or instrument, (so long as that currency or those currencies remain legal tender), or in the euro, but not in any other currency, whether or not the other currency (i) has been substituted or rep
perturbation.justification: The changed text weakens the obligations of the Company. Replacing "shall" with "endeavor to" and "will attempt to" creates ambiguity and reduces the company's commitment. The Law Explanation suggests this might violate the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing. While Scraped Law Snippet 1 does not directly address good faith and fair dealing, it provides context that Illinois law governs business transactions. The modification's move towards discretionary performance introduces potential for the company to act without genuine effort, undermining the distributor's reasonable expectations. Given that the law snippet doesn't directly address the good faith requirement, but rather provides context for Illinois business law, the contradiction is indirect, thus a MEDIUM score is appropriate.

perturbation.original_text: The Distributor, at its own expense, shall promote the distribution, sales, and use of Products in the Market.
perturbation.changed_text: The Distributor, at its own expense, should consider promoting the distribution, sales, and use of Products in the Market.
perturbation.explanation: The original text states that the distributor 'shall promote' the products, imposing a clear duty. The changed text replaces 'shall promote' with 'should consider promoting', which introduces ambiguity and makes the promotional efforts discretionary. This weakens the distributor's obligation.
perturbation.law_explanation: The weakening of the promotional obligation via the change to 'should consider promoting' impacts the spirit of the agreement which intends to ensure diligent sales activity, but also potentially undermines a sales representative's ability to earn commissions if actively discouraged from sales, thereby conflicting with the intent behind the Illinois Sales Representative Act, which protects sales representatives' rights to commissions.

BUSINESS TRANSACTIONS (815 ILCS 650/) Private Seal Abolishment Act. 815 ILCS 650/0.01 (815 ILCS 650/0.01) (from Ch. 30, par. 153a.9) Sec. 0.01. Short title. This Act may be cited as the Private Seal Abolishment Act. (Source: P.A. 86-1324.) 815 ILCS 650/1 (815 ILCS 650/1) (from Ch. 30, par. 153b) Sec. 1. The use of private seals on written contracts, deeds, mortgages or any other written instruments or documents heretofore required by law to be sealed, is hereby abolished, but the addition of a private seal to any such instrument or document shall not in any manner affect its force, validity or character, or in any way change the construction thereof. (Source: Laws 1951, p. 1299.) perturbation.justification: The changed text weakens the distributor's obligation to promote products by changing 'shall promote' to 'should consider promoting.' While the Law Explanation suggests this might undermine a sales representative's ability to earn commissions and potentially conflict with the Illinois Sales Representative Act, Scraped Law Snippet 1, the Private Seal Abolishment Act, is completely unrelated to sales commissions or representative rights. Scraped Law Snippet 2 is missing. Therefore, there is no direct legal contradiction based on the provided information. The weakening of the obligation doesn't inherently violate the Private Seal Abolishment Act, making the contradiction level low.

perturbation.original_text: Company shall at all times make reasonable efforts to maintain quality control and to deliver Products to Distributor which, when received by Distributor, or, as the case may be, the end-user, are properly and adequately packaged and contained, fully assembled (except for miscellaneous components which may be shipped separately to prevent damage in transit), fully functional and otherwise in conformance with the warranties set forth herein.
perturbation.changed_text: Company shall generally try to maintain quality control and to deliver Products to Distributor which, when received by Distributor, or, as the case may be, the end-user, appear to be reasonably packaged and contained, mostly assembled, generally functional and arguably in conformance with the warranties set forth herein.
perturbation.explanation: The original text imposes a reasonable effort to maintain quality and deliver specific product attributes. The changed text weakens this obligation through terms like 'generally try', 'appear to be reasonably packaged', 'mostly assembled', 'generally functional', and 'arguably in conformance'. This introduces significant ambiguity regarding the company's responsibility for quality and product condition.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Illinois Uniform Commercial Code - Implied Warranty of Merchantability
perturbation.law_explanation: By using subjective and vague language ('appear to be reasonably packaged', 'mostly assembled', 'generally functional'), the modified text undermines the implied warranty of merchantability under the Illinois Uniform Commercial Code (810 ILCS 5/2-314). This warranty requires that goods be fit for the ordinary purposes for which such goods are used. The changes allow for products that may not meet basic standards of functionality or packaging, contradicting the requirement of merchantability.
perturbation.scraped_snippet_1: the Guide . BUSINESS TRANSACTIONS (815 ILCS 620/) Illinois Fair Invention Development Standards Act. 815 ILCS 620/102 (815 ILCS 620/102) (from Ch. 29, par. 102) Sec. 102. Legislative intent. The purpose of this Act is to safeguard the public against fraud, deceit, imposition of financial hardship, and to foster and encourage competition, fair dealing, and prosperity in the field of idea and invention development services by prohibiting or restricting false and misleading advertising, onerous contract terms, harmful financial practices, and other unfair, dishonest, deceptive, destructive, unscrupulous, fraudulent, and discriminatory practices by which the public has been injured in connection with such development services, but not to interfere with or further regulate by this Act, those persons who provide researching, marketing, surveying, or other kinds of consulting services to professional manufacturers, marketers, publishers or others purchasing such services as an adjunct to the traditional commercial enterprises in which they engage as a livelihood. Representation of a client by an attorney in connection with the sale or licensing of an invention is not intended to be regulated by this Act. (Source: P.A. 81-542.) 815 ILCS 620/103 (815 ILCS 620/103) (from Ch. 29, par. 103) Sec. 103. Definitions. As used in this Act, unless the context otherwise requires: (a) "Invention Development Services" shall include at least one of the following: (1) evaluation of the market potential of an invention; and (2) representation of an invention to potential distributors or to potential manufacturers of the invention. (b) "Contract for invention development services" shall include a contract by which an invention developer undertakes to perform invention development services for a customer. (c) "Customer" shall include any person, firm, corporation, association, or other entity that is solicited by, inquires about or seeks the services of, or enters into a contract for invention development services with an invention developer. (d) "Invention" shall mean any discovery, process, method, apparatus, machine, design, formulation, composition, product, concept, idea or any combination thereof. (e) "Invention developer" shall mean any person, firm, corporation, association or other entity and the agents, employees or representatives of such person, firm, corporation, association, or other entity that performs invention development services, except (1) any department or agency of the federal, state or local government, (2) any charitable, scientific, educational, religious, or other organization qualified under Section 501(c)(3) or described in Section 170(b)(1)(A) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1954, as amended, or (3) any person, firm, corporation, association or other entity that does not charge a fee for invention development services. For the purposes of this paragraph, "fee" shall include any payment made by the customer to such entity including reimbursements for expenditures made or costs incurred by such entity but shall not include any payment made from a portion of the income received by a customer by virtue of invention development services performed by such entity. (Source: P.A. 81-542.) 815 ILCS 620/Art. II (815 ILCS 620/Art. II heading) ARTICLE II. DISCLOSURES MADE PRIOR TO CONTRACT 815 ILCS 620/201 (815 ILCS 620/201) (from Ch. 29, par. 201) Sec. 201. Disclosure of fee in advertising. Every invention developer who charges a fee or requires any consideration for his
perturbation.justification: The modified contract introduces ambiguity regarding the company's responsibility for product quality and condition, which indirectly contradicts the implied warranty of merchantability. The law explanation suggests this is based on the Illinois Uniform Commercial Code (810 ILCS 5/2-314) and that the changes allow for products that may not meet basic standards of functionality or packaging. Scraped Law Snippet 1 relates to the Illinois Fair Invention Development Standards Act (815 ILCS 620/), which does not appear directly relevant to the scenario, however, it is an Illinois law snippet provided which can be considered. Scraped Law Snippet 2 is unavailable. Therefore, the contradiction is categorized as MEDIUM, as the altered terms may weaken a general standard of merchantability but does not explicitly contradict a specific statutory requirement in Snippet 1.
